title: CTRL0000042646 - Transcribed Interview of Andrew Surabian, (February 8, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:00
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
It is 10 o'clock in the morning.
This is a deposition of Andrew Surabian conducted by the House Select Committee
to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol, pursuant to House
Mr. Surabian -- and I hope I'm pronouncing your last name correct -- could you
please state your full name and spell your last name for the record.
Now, could you raise your right hand, and the reporter
will swear you in for the deposition.
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under the penalties of perjury
that the testimony you are about to give in this matter will be the truth, the whole truth,
Sir, this will be a staff-led deposition, and members of the committee may, of
course, join and choose also to ask questions, as may my colleagues.
I'm a senior investigative counsel for the
committee, and joining me by -- in the room is -- I don't know if you can see him, but a
I also have another colleague, investigative counsel, by the name of
If members do join, you'll see them show up on the Webex, and then I'll take a
brief moment to pause and let the record reflect that they're in.
see any members that are on, okay?
But, as of now, I don't
Now, we're going to follow the House deposition rules that we've provided to
Mr. Bean and your other attorneys with you.
counsel to please place -- state their names for the record.
And, under those rules, you're permitted to have
So, at this time, I'm going to ask your
And -- but, before I do so, I'll say that I understand that your counsel are going to
place an objection on the record, and I'll get to a point before we start the questioning,
Mr. Surabian, where I'll allow them to do that.
But, Mr. Bean, if you could just now introduce yourself and have your colleagues
On behalf of Mr. Surabian, we have -- go ahead, Christopher.
If you -- you want to come on over, and, Jared, come on over just so
Christopher Wesley Dempsey on behalf of Andy
Jared Burns, also on behalf of Mr. Surabian.
And Daniel Bean, in the law firm of Abel Bean Law, on
just for the record is -- well, we'll get to it in a moment, but, under the House deposition
rules, Mr. Surabian, neither committee members nor staff may discuss the substance of
your testimony that you provide today unless the committee approves release.
Now, you yourself are free to tell anyone you want or no one.
Now, you and your attorney will also have an opportunity to review the transcript
Before we begin, I'll just go over a few ground rules.
There is, as you now know,
an official court reporter transcribing the record of this deposition.
And, for the record, I see that, you know, Mr. Bean and his colleagues and you,
Mr. Surabian, are in different locations.
So, if at any point you need to consult with
Mr. Bean and your attorneys, that's fine.
Just let us know, and we'll turn our camera off
and go on mute, and you do the same, and you can talk in private, okay?
Now, as we go and for the benefit of the court reporter, if you can just please wait
until each question is asked completely before you begin your response, and then I'll wait
for you to complete your response before I ask my next question.
reporter can make a clear record of what each person is saying.
And the reporter can't record nonverbal responses, such as you shaking your head
So, when we get to a place, if I ask a question and you do shake or nod your
head or say, you know, something to the effect of uh-huh, excuse me, but I'll just ask you
to say yes or no or to explain in words.
And, similarly, if you say a name or refer to something and we need to have it
spelled for the record, the reason I'll stop and ask you to do that, again, is just for the
We ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
the question is not clear, just ask, and we'll do our best to clarify.
done within just a couple hours or so.
And, again, we talked about the need for any breaks.
Also, if you just need a
You know, we aim -- as I've told Mr. Bean, our goal is to be
But, if at any point you need a comfort break, tell
We might break every hour or so just to, you know, keep us fresh, okay?
Throughout the deposition, I have a colleague who will be putting exhibits up on
And so, when we refer you to a
document, take whatever time you need to look at it and familiarize yourself with it
Now, yesterday, I provided Mr. Bean and his colleagues with access to a -- what I
call a drop box with the exhibits that we have for today, so they're the same ones that we
print or save them, but they are the same ones.
Now, I know because of document security purposes, you couldn't
And, if I could just ask my colleague, he or she is going to place on the screen
exhibit 1, which is just the subpoena for today's proceeding, okay?
And this is a good test run to see if you can see that.
maximize it so we can get in close so it shows up on your screen.
It's still a little bit small on the display.
make it take up the whole screen.
I don't know if there's a way to
But, for the time being, we won't get caught up on it.
Mr. Surabian, do you see that first page of exhibit 1 is a subpoena addressed to
I'm going to ask if they can
So that's -- that's the subpoena for today.
And, as I understand it, Mr. Bean has an objection he'd like to place on the record,
so I'll pause at this moment.
And, Mr. Bean, please feel free to do so.
Mr. Surabian objects to the instant deposition proceedings as the select
committee is not properly and duly authorized in accordance with House Resolution 503,
section 2(a), 117th Congress, 2021, as it is not comprised of 13 Members, five of whom
were appointed after consultation with the minority leader.
Additionally, Mr. Surabian objects to the instant deposition proceedings as the
subpoena purporting to compel his appearance does not further a valid legal purpose
ancillary to legislative authority but, rather, serves a quintessentially law enforcement
purpose preserved to the authority of the executive branch of the United States, to wit,
investigate facts, circumstances, and causes, as well as expose and punish alleged criminal
All of those are proffered objectives of the select committee and thus are
Also, Mr. Surabian, objects to his constitutional rights being violated, the instant
deposition proceedings, as the subpoena purporting to compel Mr. Surabian's
appearance violates his constitutional rights, including but not limited to his First
Amendment right to freedom of speech, his First Amendment right of freedom of
assembly, his Fourth Amendment right to be free of unreasonable search and seizures, his
Fourth Amendment right that warrants be issued only upon a finding of probable cause,
and his Fifth Amendment right to due process of law.
Lastly, Mr. Surabian finally objects to the instant deposition proceedings as the
subpoena purporting to compel his appearance violates the separation of power
waiving these objections, Mr. Surabian respectfully submits to his examination under
oath before the select committee, except where specifically objected to by counsel, as
necessary, as we proceed through this deposition.
Notwithstanding the aforementioned objections, subject to and without
Thank you, counsel, for allowing me to put Mr. Surabian's objections on the
record, and he is now available to answer your questions.
And I won't respond to the objections, but I just note for the record that the select
committee does not agree with the characterizations or your assertions about the
That said, we appreciate that Mr. Surabian will be answering questions today.
And, Mr. Surabian, as Mr. Bean said, you know, you may only refuse to answer a
question to preserve a privilege recognized by the select committee, and, if he objects,
make sure you wait for Mr. Bean to explain that objection, and then we can discuss it.
If you refuse to answer a question based on a privilege, I can either proceed with
the deposition or seek a ruling from the chairman of the committee on the objection.
And, if the chairman were to overrule such an objection, you'd be required to answer the
I also want to remind you, as we do all witnesses, that it is unlawful to deliberately
Since this deposition is under oath, providing
false information could result in criminal penalties, to include for perjury or providing
Do you understand everything we've talked about?
Do you have any questions before we get started?
So, Mr. Surabian, how old are you?
And just what State do you live in?
I understand that you served in President Trump's administration at the start
I was there from January to September 2017.
And what role did you play?
I'll note for the record that we just heard a message from Webex
that said the meeting is being recorded, and I should have noted at the start,
Mr. Surabian, that we are video recording all interviews or depositions, as Mr. Bean
knows, and so that's why that says that there, okay?
But we were talking about your time in the White House in 2017.
was your title or role during that time?
I was a special assistant to the President and deputy strategist.
And, since the time that you left the White House, what has been your
career path in the years since?
I started my own consulting company and consult for campaigns, and I do
And what's the name of your company?
Now, as part of the consulting work that you do with Belmont, is one of your
I wouldn't characterize him as a client because he's never paid me.
So do you have a professional relationship with Mr. Trump?
How would you like me to refer so there is no confusion just throughout?
What would you prefer me to say?
So do you have a -- what -- what, if any, is the nature of your professional
We have a personal friendship, first and foremost.
I've advised him on political matters like endorsements.
And so, in the time since you left -- 2017 and through today, on
occasion and in the capacity as being a friend, you'll advise him, but he hasn't paid you for
any of the advice you've given him?
And is -- do you have -- do you provide advice or consulting services
And do you provide any such services to any other member of the Trump
family, you know, whether Don Jr.'s siblings or in-laws?
I currently advise, or my firm advises the Save America PAC, but no
And, just as I -- the Save America PAC, just briefly, how, if at
all, is that connected with the Trump family?
I believe it's a leadership PAC for former President Trump.
Now, the -- do you know a gentleman by the name of Arthur Schwartz?
And what is your -- the nature of your relationship with Mr. Schwartz?
We're friends, and we have worked on some PR projects together.
Does he also provide similar consulting or PR work to -- to Don Jr., to your
Now, do you know a gentleman by the name of Taylor Budowich?
And how do you know Mr. Budowich?
I met Taylor 10 years ago when we were both working for Tea Party Express.
And, currently, do the two of you have a professional relationship?
He is also an adviser to Save America.
And, as I understand it, did the two of you help Don Jr. with setting up the
Don Jr. had no involvement in Save the Senate PAC outside of appearing in
Me and Taylor ran Save the U.S. Senate PAC.
And then do you know a woman by the name of Caroline Wren?
And how do you know Ms. Wren?
I believe I first met her during the 2020 Trump campaign.
Did she serve any -- do you understand her to be a fundraiser?
Did she provide any fundraising services to any entity of which you're -- that
you worked with, whether your own company or to any PAC that you worked with?
The only time I've worked directly with Caroline in a professional manner
was she served as one of our fundraisers for Save the U.S. Senate PAC.
Now, I want to focus on the 2020 -- the Presidential election.
Did you, Mr. Surabian, have any role with the campaign -- with President Trump's
I was an adviser to the campaign.
And was that true throughout the course of the election, or did that
end at some point before election day?
I advised the campaign -- I can't remember exactly when I started, but I
advised the campaign through the election and left as of November 15th, 2020.
And you anticipated my next question.
Did you provide any services to the campaign after the election regarding the
efforts to challenge the results of the Presidential election?
Now, before we get to talk about really the January 6th events, which is
going to be the crux of what we're discussing today, I just want to talk some process at
the front end that I'm sure Mr. Bean has previewed for you, just about the document
appreciate you having gone through your records, and I just want to ask a few questions
We've received documents from you, and we very much
So, as what I saw in the production is that you produced a -- you know, a number
of emails from what looks to be a Yahoo account that you use.
So is that the email -- the only email address you use to -- to
communicate about the -- the events that were covered by the subpoena?
And one of the exhibits we provided yesterday and we'll go
through today are phone records that we obtained from a -- your cell phone provider, but
is it right that you have a cell phone with the last four digits ending i n -
And what type of cell phone was that, at least during the time we're talking
about, in January of 2021 or December of 2020?
Now, do you have the same iPhone currently that you were using back then?
Did you -- I didn't see, but tell me if I'm wrong.
production that was made on your behalf any sort of text messages that you exchanged
with anyone about the -- the subjects that are covered by the subpoena.
So, just as a personal practice, you have your texts delete after some amount
My texts have been set to auto expire for a while now.
I mean, I got a call from the FBI following -- sometime after the 2020
election, and they told me that they believed a foreign actor hacked my Apple email,
which led me to take some safeguards with all my communications.
And so -- but -- so, as a result of that, you changed your kind of data preservation
That would be a pretty bracing call to get.
Did you use during the time we're talking about -- so, again, late 2020 into January
example, and you let me know.
using any of those platforms to communicate with folks about the stuff we're going to
And I'll just list a few, but these are just an
Signal or WhatsApp or Telegram or Parler, were you
I have a Signal account, but I handed my phone over to my lawyers, who
gave it to a third-party vendor, and they imaged it, and what you have is what I had.
Any other means you would have communicated electronically about the events
we'll talk about today and covered by the subpoena other than your phone or your
So, then, let's -- we can get into the kind of facts around and the lead-up to
Are you familiar with a woman by the name of Julie Fancelli?
And I imagine -- you hesitated a bit.
And I only became aware of her when there was a media article about
But you're aware of who she is now and are --
As we understand it, she donated some amount of money to the Save the
U.S. Senate PAC in or around December of 2020.
Did you know that at the time?
I'm going to object to pertinency.
It has no -- nothing to do with the
facts, circumstances, or causes of the events of January 6th.
Can you tell me what the pertinency of it is, please?
Dan, it's simply because, I think, as you saw from an example,
Taylor Budowich and Caroline Wren that, as part of Ms. Fancelli donated the money, she
also donated to the Save the Senate, so it naturally would have bled to Taylor talking to
It's not about to get into the business of Save America.
Taylor did not tell me anything about her until there was about to
be a media story after January 6th, and he called me up, and he said:
something to the effect of -- hey, just want to give you a heads up.
going to be a story -- I forget where it was -- and it's going to mention Save the U.S.
Senate PAC, because one of the people who donated to our super-PAC also, I guess, gave
And, if we -- let me -- if we look at exhibit -- well, let
me ask this first, Mr. Surabian.
Do you remember when you first learned -- as best you
can -- when you first learned about the rally on January 6th was going to take place on
Do you remember who you learned it from and approximately
I wasn't following it very closely.
So, you know, what I'll show you is just a way to try and set a
timeline and see if that refreshes your recollection, is, if someone -- if my colleague can
pull up exhibit 8 on the screen.
So, as you can see there on the screen -- I'll stop right there on page 1,
and I'll represent to you this is a text message chain between Taylor Budowich and
Caroline Wren, and you'll see that it starts on Saturday, December 26.
And, if you go down -- scroll down on that first page, and just a
You're going to see that -- and stop right there.
That Ms. Wren -- she's in blue, so that's an iPhone chat message, text to
Guess what the budget is she just gave me for a bus
Mr. Budowich responds with an LOL.
some for Save the U.S. Senate.
Now, I imagine Save the U.S. Senate is referring to the PAC that we just
And, again, we're not talking about the substance, but just the fact that
that's the PAC that you and Mr. Budowich started together, it appears?
Now, several times during today -- and it's just so we can ground the time
And, at the time, was Ms. Wren on contract as a fund raiser for
and date -- I'll refer to exhibit 9, which I'll ask my colleague to bring up on the screen.
And, Mr. Surabian, these are what I call an annotated version of phone records for
records to compare them to see that what I did is I took these to make them easier to
read and then, also, just highlighted certain numbers and put names next to them and
also provided in exhibit 12 to you and your counsel a list of subscriber information to
establish that the people that we've listed, the numbers we've associated, are their
I provided your counsel and hopefully you were able to see the raw phone
And so, as you see on exhibit 9, the first page covered days early in December, but
if we go to page 2, and we stop right there, near the top of page 2, you'll see when you
read the exhibit -- and hopefully you got familiar with it yesterday, but I'll explain it
now -- that, on the left, you'll see the date and time of any communication or a record
The next is going to be if it's incoming or outgoing.
The next column is going to be the number that you were communicating with.
And the next after that is the duration in seconds.
And a feature of the date/time is that you'll see in parentheses next to the time
"GMT" and whether there is any change off of GMT.
mean time, which means you have to subtract five to understand the time, so just
Other times, when it's GMT plus zero, that's just at Greenwich
But you'll see that, on December 26th in the afternoon, that the records show that
Mr. Budowich called you at approximately 2 in the afternoon, or 2:10 p.m., and it looks
like there was a call for a couple of minutes.
Now, I don't imagine you're going to remember this day after Christmas,
Mr. Budowich calling, but as best you can remember, was it Mr. Budowich who put on
your radar about this event on January 6th that he and Ms. Wren were working on?
So I cannot recall this conversation.
I don't know when -- I can't remember
when, but at some point, Taylor mentioned to me that he was helping with the rally and
floated to me that, if I was looking for any, you know, other work, that they could
probably use some help doing PR.
And I told him, you know, thanks for thinking of me, but my plate was full, and I
So, when -- who did Mr. Budowich tell you he was working with on this
I don't know that he said at the time.
Did you come to learn before it happened that Caroline Wren was involved?
And did Mr. Budowich explain to you particularly what he was doing on
I don't know what exactly the capacity was.
Did Mr. Budowich have prior experience organizing events of this sort,
maybe from his Tea Party Express days, or do you know?
So it seemed natural that he'd be working on something like this
And you said that you were -- it sounds like you declined the opportunity to
work on this because you were too busy.
Just generally, what were you too busy with?
My focus after the election was the Georgia Senate races, and I -- that's what
I was following at the time, and I just wasn't in a place where I was looking for a new
Now, is it right that Katrina Pierson -- and the last name is P-i-e-r-s-o-n -- that
you came to know that she was involved in working with Taylor and others on this event
She -- and I believe you have these documents.
who -- she asked me at one point if Don was speaking at the rally.
And I said, no, not to my knowledge.
And then, a little bit later, she was the one who informed me that he was
speaking, and that's how I came to know that she was involved.
I mean, I wasn't involved in the planning or the preparations
And there are going to be questions that -- I know you
referenced that -- it's clear we -- you know, we may already know the answer to, are
going to be covered by documents, but understand, for the process, I'll go through and
just ask you just to get your perspective, but I appreciate that.
Is Ms. Pierson someone that you knew of before this time you had dealt with
I met Katrina the same -- in the same time period that I met Taylor.
Doing the grassroots work with Tea Party Express and otherwise
I -- I believe we all met together in 2012 in Texas.
Now, we talked about Mr. Schwartz earlier.
have any role in organizing or planning the -- the rally on the 6th in D.C.?
And do you know or at least know now that that event was sponsored
by -- that is, the rally on the Ellipse -- was sponsored by Women for America First?
And the women behind Women for America First are Amy and
And did you know the Kremers, or at least Amy, from your time with Tea
Now, I'm going to show you -- if I could ask my colleague to bring up
And if we can zoom out a bit
This is a tweet -- a screen capture of a tweet that President Trump put out on
December 19th of 2020, and the first part of the tweet references a report by Peter
And, again, that's after saying that Mr. Navarro had a report about election fraud
more than sufficient to swing the victory to Trump.
Do you remember seeing this tweet at the time it came out and that the President
was calling for people to come to D.C.?
Big protest in D.C. on January 6th.
I don't recall if I saw the tweet, but I -- I saw that there was an event on the
And, when you learned about the event on the 6th before it
happened, did you come to learn that the President would be speaking at that event?
I only learned of that when it was -- I saw it announced publicly.
So, even -- even -- that was even after you had been asked -- and we'll get to
this -- by Ms. Pierson whether Don Jr. would be speaking?
Now, President Trump, in this tweet and then subsequent tweets and at the
event itself, the focus was on, in his words and others, stopping the steal of the
Have you yourself been involved -- after you stopped advising the Presidential
campaign in mid-November, had you been involved in any efforts to -- to challenge -- just
generally, to challenge or protest the results of the Presidential election?
Was your focus entirely, from mid-November until January 6th, on the
Georgia Senate runoff or the Senate races?
It was the bulk of my focus.
Now, were you aware at the time that they happened that the
Kremers and others came to D.C. for a -- what I'll call generally a "stop the steal" protest
Were you aware of that at the time?
I was living in D.C. at that time.
And I imagine you didn't come to D.C. for that event?
I moved into my new house in
Massachusetts, I believe, the week of Thanksgiving, and didn't come back to D.C. until
So you were still in town on November 14th, but I -- just to close this loop, I
imagine you didn't go to the rally in Freedom Plaza or downtown on that day?
So, then, that also answers, since you moved, that you weren't in town on
December 12th of 2020 -- and, when I say "town," I mean D.C. -- for the next rally that the
Kremers and others put on in town on behalf of the "stop the steal" movement?
That is correct, and I can clear the field and tell you I didn't attend any
I didn't catch the last part of that answer.
I can clear the deck and tell you that I didn't attend any
rallies for anything during that period.
And, to that point, Mr. Surabian, I'll show -- I'll ask my colleague to
put up exhibit 2, and just hold on one moment until it showed -- it pops up.
What we have here is a capture of a text message.
It's a series of text messages that Amy Kremer sent to you but you didn't respond
And if we can zoom in, she says:
Hey, are y'all coming to Atlanta tonight?
Wanted to make sure you know about the FB, or Facebook, group being shut down.
They have hacked the website, and mailchimp has shut us down.
So I guess I should ask:
On occasion, do you communicate with Amy Kremer?
Not about this, but I imagine you all have each other's phone numbers?
We have each other's phone numbers, and I might get a text from her from
time to time over the years, but I can't recall the last time I spoke to her.
And this -- this -- these texts that she sent you were on
November 5th of 2020, so, you know, 2 days after the election, and there is no response.
And so I imagine you didn't communicate with her about this event in Atlanta or
And did you even know that she was also doing a bus tour in support
of the "stop the steal" movement, you know, across the country in addition to the two
Were you tracking that at all?
I may have seen it, but, again, it wasn't something that I was following.
Now, about the "stop the steal" movement generally, and about, you
know -- you had in an email exchange with a Huffington Post reporter that you provided
to us -- I imagine you had a chance to review that, but you were very clear with the
reporter that it wasn't something you were tweeting about, it wasn't something you were
Is that all correct when you told the reporter that?
And can you provide more color?
know -- whatever word you want to use, you were very clear with them that -- that this
was just not something you were involved in.
I mean, the email says what the email says, but it just wasn't something that
I was focused on at the time.
It wasn't something that I was really following.
Now, you did produce -- and we can show them, but I can also just
explain -- two calendar invites for surrogate calls on behalf of the -- President Trump's
Have you looked at those and are aware of having
And those -- you know, we can look at exhibit 4.
from January 4th of 2021, and it's setting a call for later that day and saying the speakers
are Rudy Giuliani and Jason Miller.
Why were you on this email list for surrogates?
I assume it -- it was just the campaign's list, and I was
Do you recall calling in -- excuse me -- calling in to this one on January 4th or
the other one you produced an invite for on January 5th?
And I don't believe or I don't recall calling in to any surrogate calls
after I was off the campaign's payroll on November 15th.
So, then, if we can look at exhibit 7 to the point, as you brought up, with
Ms. Pierson reaching out to you about Don Jr. about the event or the rally.
This is, I'll represent to you, text messages that Ms. Pierson produced to the select
committee, including this chain between her and you and Mr. Budowich, okay?
And, if we zoom out, actually, so we can show you the top.
Katrina's -- it's her iPhone to Mr. Budowich and to you.
She was blocking out the numbers.
And the first message that we see in this chain is that she sends, on
December 27th of 2020, at 6:17 p.m., a schedule for the March for Trump tour, which is
the Women for America First, and the last stop on that is January 6th in Washington, D.C.
Now, we looked earlier, Mr. Surabian, at the message Mr. Budowich exchanged
with Ms. Wren the day prior, December 26th, about the money from Ms. Fancelli coming.
So do you remember why Ms. Pierson was writing to the two of you, Mr. Budowich and
you, on this day on December 27th with this tour?
Now, if we can just -- we're going to go through -- what I'm going to do is break up
the timeline and go from this date to January 1st and just see what you remember about
those days as best you can, okay?
And I'll do that by looking at exhibit 9 again, so I'll ask my colleague to bring that
up, which are your phone records.
And I'm going to frame this by -- well, why don't
I -- I'll show you this, and we'll see where we're at.
zoom out just a little bit so we can see a little bit more of each page.
If we can go to page 2, and if we can
But you can see here these are records -- this page that we're looking at are going
to cover from the end of Christmas, December 25th, through December 29th, or towards
And I'll just highlight calls with certain people.
Now, you've talked about Mr. Schwartz and Mr. Budowich.
I know her from the Trump campaign.
So is she -- did you have a professional relationship with her at this time?
Did you provide any sort of consulting services to her or any family members?
Is it right -- is she the Emily Moreno who is engaged to be married to
Max Miller now, to your knowledge?
And do you know Mr. Miller?
I've spoken to him once in my life.
Did you have -- when you talked to Ms. Moreno at
this time, was it -- did it have anything to do with the events of January 6th or planning
I don't recall the specific conversations, but I suspect they were about her
And so you see on that page, again, you've got calls with
It seems like that would be in the ordinary course.
And would it be natural, too, to be talking to Mr. Budowich, even if it wasn't
about the January 6th event, given the Save the U.S. Senate PAC?
So, if we then turn to the next page, or page 3, you know, you see, if
we just kind of -- if we look at the records that carry on from the 29th through really New
Year's Day, you know, there are a handful -- a couple calls with Taylor Budowich, one with
Mr. Schwartz, and there is one call with Don Jr.
And, again, this is before the new year.
Do you think, before Katrina reached out to you to ask if he was speaking, that you
would have been talking with Mr. -- with Don Jr. about the event on the 6th by this point?
And, on New Year's Eve, it's -- it -- maybe it's a text message -- there is a
quick outgoing -- well, it's 2 seconds -- in connection with Caroline Wren.
don't know if that was a Happy New Vear or what it is, but would it be normal for you on
